subject: Law
title: IP Clause in the US Constitution
description: A quick win: understand IP Clause in the US Constitution.

hook.text: The Founders cared about innovation so much they wrote IP protection directly into the Constitution.

buildup.text: Article I, Section 8 empowers Congress to grant patents and copyrights to promote progress.

discovery.text: The clause says 'for limited times'â€”the Founders wanted IP rights to expire, not last forever.

twist.text: Congress has extended copyright terms repeatedly. Mickey Mouse's copyright expiration kept getting pushed back.

climax.text: Critics argue these extensions serve corporations, not creators, undermining the clause's original purpose.

punchline.text: The Constitution grants IP rights. It also meant them to end.

quiz.question: What does the Constitution say about IP protection duration?
options: It should be for limited times
